column529: Comment

column1: Graceful degradation when archive is full
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
column33:
By way of Josh at OBAC/SEGA, behavior when archiving partitions fill up it typically results in a downward spiral for SOFA. It would be preferred that SOFA continue to reliability service streaming applications even if archiving fails (for any reason).

Some observed behavior/symptoms:
* High rate of logging to /var/log when archiving is failing, which causes cascade failures due to /var/log filling
* downstream streaming apps stop functioning (no further details at this point, could be 2nd or N-ary cascade failures

Marked as _low_ priority. Procedural workarounds exist to detect and recover. Ok to move to triage/backlog.

sofa:

heo/pcid/Pcid256_SoS.h

heo/pcid/Pcid1296_SoS.h

heo/pcid/Pcid1792_SoI.h

heo/include/ImageSegmentHeader.h

heo/pcid/Pcid1792_SoI.h

warning: ‘void* memset(void*, int, size_t)’ clearing an object of non-trivial type ‘class ImageSegmentHeaderWrapper’; use assignment or value-initialization instead

(Check cppcheck and clang-tidy to see if they're finding these; if so, expland to fix this elsewhere.  It's a "it probably works but we have no guarantee that it does" thing.

column1: Document HDF5R Writer UDP/Filexfer
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
column33:
Out of the box, it looks like "gilossrv" HDF5-R Writer ({{hdf5rWriter}}) is blasting a UDP copy of every HDF5 file written. This is controlled by command line opt {{-U}}, and the {{gccommon}} seems to set this unconditionally. Looks like it might be disabled via environment {{FILEXSRV_APP_READY_PORT=0}} (e.g. in /etc/sysconfig/gilossrv). I think this or similar also applies to HDF5-H and to VCDU.

This is important because it causes additional IO load on the archive storage backend, and less importantly network and cpu load.

Keywords: FILEXSRV_APP_READY_PORT, fileTransferUDPport

Code ref:
* https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/sofa-hdf5/browse/src/hemi-hdf5r/ScaWriteThread.C#1218
* https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/sofa-admin/browse/scripts/gccommon.sh#1198
column146:
Success:
* {{FILEXSRV_APP_READY_PORT}} is documented, assuming that is the "best" way to toggle this feature

Better success:
* Expected use cases for when/why this UDP function is desired is documented, along with recommended settings for how to deploy & configure the capability

column1: Remove IRIX64 support in CfgMgr and remove deprecated headers
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems. column33:
Found during a review of our code formatter, since it looks a little weird here...

common_core, src/common-core/configuration/CfgMgr.C has a preprocessor block at the top for IRIX64 compatibility.  IRIX is a discontinued operating system for machines nobody uses any more, so we can remove this section.

However, the non-IRIX section #includes strstream.h which is a deprecated header.  The IRIX section is actually correct (use <sstream>).

This task is to clean this up.

(Note: as an aesthetic issue, also clean up the for-loop in operator<< using auto and range-based for loop.)
column146: IRIX compatibility section removed, and proper headers included.

column1: Update SOFA to use gpsrapid.out instead of gpsrapid.daily file for Earth Orientation Parameters
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
column33: SOFA currently uses the gpsrapid.daily file for EOPs.  This file only contains the last 90 days worth of parameters.  This is only good for live data processing or generation of HDF5 data for the past 90 days.  Recommend using the IERS gpsrapid.out file, which contains values since May 1992.  So if I want to playback VCDU to make HDF5 from two years ago, I don't have to go find the gpsrapid.daily file from that period and swap it out.

This story:
 # Reviews and edits the entire App Dev Guide for consistency
 # Gets feedback from the app developers (e.g. Robert, Matt) for concurrence and comments

At the end of the story, we will have a consistent App Dev Guide in line with the original intent of SOFA-787 but may still have some content to change based on feedback that will be addressed in the follow-on story SOFA-790.
column251: We talked IRL about this, but we have a clear plan forward for refactoring and making the app dev guide organized a little more clearly, mainly by removing the old and new headings, putting the old on the same level as the other things, and perhaps moving some other sub-pages around under the toolkit side.

column33:
New story as of 2.5

Separate out the toolkit content from the App Dev Guide since it appears to be over-emphasized and not in line with its usefulness. Keep it available as a reference, but essentially it needs to be archived. Don't clean it up, just separate it out and reference it from what's left of the App Dev Guide.

At the end of the story, the App Dev Guide will have all toolkit content removed but referenced. The overall structure will still need some work, which will be addressed in the follow-on story, SOFA-787.

column33:
The 3.6 and 3.7 code deliveries are completely independent; the git repos have (via some clever use of git) been convinced that 3.7 is a commit on top of 3.6.  We need to verify (just a spot check will do) that this was done properly.

 

 Do: Double check (vs what's in the source rpm) that the git import used to bring these versions into compliance correctly copied files and history
column146: Done: Independent verification that  each version has the right set of files, and spot checks on a few files that have changed.

column1: Clarify and/or refine dependency on NORM
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
column33:
In SOFA 1.3.1, there is a new dependency (hard or soft (?)) on NORM for DSPSRV. I'm interested in refining this. If NORM is a non-optional/hard dependency, lets look for the right RPM/SPEC to encode the dependency. Even if that is a "blackbox" rpm, we can work with that by unpacking the binary rpm and editing the metadata. If it is an optional/soft dependency, then we should make sure the context is understood and in sync between the (Chef) provisioning code, and build in the right "feature flag (attribute)" in provisioning to match SOFA docs/conops.

As an aside, I'm pretty certain that NORM (Nack oriented reliable multicast) is not a feature used in TAP or OBAC/SEGA at the moment.

Also, it probably makes sense to fully on-board NORM if its a hard dep. We can develop a RPM spec and work with NRL to add them into the upstream NORM SCM. Then we can setup a TAP build, scan, package, publish pipeline to put NORM RPMs into the TAP/SEGA/SOFA baseline and repos. (But this paragraph should be a different ticket.)

cc [~justin.mercier]
column251: Concur!
column529: Oct 07, 2020 10:25 PM;james.flemer;[~david.steffen] I see you added this into an active sprint. IMO, it's "medium" priority (possibly low). I won't complain if you want to put it into a future sprint instead.
column530:
Oct 08, 2020 1:39 PM;david.steffen;OK.  My concern was about this affecting installation of SOFA 1.3.1.  If we can go with it as is for now, we can revisit for SOFA 1.4.

Thanks

As delivered in the Bidder's Library, there are two sources of DRs:
 # HEMI Comprehensive Application Assessment -25-Jul-2016.pdf (the "MITRE") report
 # HEMI_Test_Report_v3.6.1.pd

This epic is to capture DRs from these two delivered assessments, *as they apply to the working code base.* If any of the issues in these reports have been resolved in the code base received by us, we should notify the customer.

(Note that the code in 3.7.2 does not seem to have any MITRE-reported issues fixed).

We may want to expand this epic to include issues found by E.G. CppCheck... this to be determined.

column1: SOFA Resource Guide
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code. column33:
The definition of this document has changed.  See below for the old discussion.  Note that the SOW calls this document out as a deliverable, but has no text describing its contents.  Note also that this document is very different from the HEMI 3.7.2 "User's Guide", which has been subsumed into the SOFA 101 training document, and possibly some ICDs.

This is the "Welcome to SOFA" document, written for all users, containing:
 * Guide to resources (where to look for things, what documents exist to answer your questions)
 * FAQ
 * Links to the Forum.  (Or, arguably, *is* the Forum?)

 

 

-------------------------------

(Original description):

This will be a repackaging of the HEMI User Guide.  The intended audience is (from that document):

"personnel who generate and use the data outputs from [various HEMI capabilities].  This document produces guidance to assist the HEMI User with configuring those capabilities to generate the desired output and interpreting the output, especially with respect to warnings and errors".

So, intended for people who are trying to use the output of HEMI directly (as opposed to having an App process data and give them some results).

column33:
This document isn't mentioned by name in the SOW, but we believe it ought to be the second sentence:

_4.4.8 (U) SciTec shall create a SOFA Developer's Guide for each programming language that is similar to commercial application developer guide. SciTec shall document in the SOFA Developer’s Guide the procedures to execute the SOFA build, regressing testing, packaging, and deployment processes. (Prototype Deliverable PD01)_

This documents processed used by the SOFA Custodians to maintain and develop the SOFA code base.  It includes:
 * Coding standards (naming conventions, error handling, etc)
 * How to run the SOFA factory tests
 * How to maintain and use the SOFA factory CI/CD Pipeline (no small task)
 ** Includes the Pipeline Architecture and description
 * GIT issues such as branch procedures, log message conventions, code review procedures, etc
 * How to deliver a SOFA build.
 * References the Software Architecture Document
 ** Might include lower-level architectural issues such as consistent error-handling strategies.

column33:
From James Flemer:

HEMI archive data use is configurable and not based on filesystem size (i.e. archive multiple products to same volume without space management problems in fileclean).
 * Investigate – does this make sense, do we want to do it?
column251: This is real at SEGA now.
column529:
May 06, 2020 4:54 PM;james.flemer;This problem is real with a scale out storage solution (e.g. Gluster). Both TAP and OBAC are moving to scale out real soon now.
cc [~jason.antico]
column530: May 06, 2020 5:02 PM;jason.antico;I've got a plan in mind for the TAP using our Mongo database (since I want to be able to search the rolling archive metadata anyways), but a simpler mechanism may be to clean up based on age of files not the size of the volume.  Just run a cron job to delete any directories older than a certain number of days (user configured based on how big the volume is and the typical daily archive size).

column1: FOSS: Pull lodepng out of SOFA, approval process, RPM-ize
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
column33:
Ditto SOFA-918, this open-source project was just dumped into the SOFA code base at some point.

[https://github.com/lvandeve/lodepng]

It looks like this is the intended use.  However, we should really bring it in as an external submod.  Alternate, create an RPM.  Either way this will require scanning, TAP Lab approval, etc.

Alternately, are there other open-source PNG encoder/decoders out there?  Are any of them packaged as RHEL packages?  If so, are they already approved by the TAP Lab?
column251: See SOFA-1774, which is the right way to handle this code if we need to keep using it (along with required build updates for scanning, etc)
column529:
Dec 19, 2019 3:20 PM;colin.reininger;Will need to test sofa-video to confirm whether we need to keep a png library in sofa.

The lodePNG code in SOFA was modified to include C++ wrapper classes for encoding/decoding. If we decide to continue to use this library, will need to update (or make from scratch) wrappers to work with lodePNG as a submodule, along with getting scanned and TAP approved.

A possible alternative is the official png library: libpng, version 1.2.5 available in rhel7. [http://www.libpng.org/pub/png/libpng.html]

C++ wrapper project for libpng, png++ (last update ~2015): [https://www.nongnu.org/pngpp/]
column530: Nov 03, 2020 3:47 PM;david.steffen;Can we confirm that we even need this code any more?  If it's only needed for sofa-video, we can just delete it (and possibly dump it into the sofa-video repo just for documentation purposes).
column531: Nov 03, 2020 3:47 PM;david.steffen;See SOFA-1774, which is the right way to handle this code if we need to keep using it (along with required build updates for scanning, etc)

column33:
The cppzmq project code [https://github.com/zeromq/cppzmq] was dumped directly into the sofa-core codebase (possibly in violation of the open-source licence). 
 # Remove this file from our code base. and instead, generate an RPM based on the version used.
 # Obtain an RPM for this version.
 ## There may be a RHEL RPM for this, but I don't think so.  Use one if there is (add it to our Nexus Yum repo).
 ## Make a Jenkins job to take this code and generate an RPM.  Add this to our deliverables
 ## Note: don't use an RPM from non-RHEL source.  A highly-trusted repo might be OK (epel repo); check with Bryan Boyd. (This part is probably a Dave thing)
 # If we're building the RPM ourselves, hook up our scanning tools.  There's a ticket for coordinating this with Bryan Boyd @ TAP Lab; this part may be blocked by that ticket.
 # Ideally, add our RPM to the TAP Lab's yum repo.
column251: Possibly, this is OBE with the C++ SDK.  We can probably build a better version anyway, or (at least) build our thing without this.
column529:
Jan 08, 2020 3:23 PM;david.steffen;Note: we don't need an RPM for delivery, since this is header-only.  We might want an RPM for our build environment.  Or, we might pull it in as an extern submodule; we should discuss.

(But either way, we'll still need to scan & run by the TAP Lab for approval)
column530: Feb 04, 2020 5:25 PM;david.steffen;Possibly, this is OBE with the C++ SDK.  We can probably build a better version anyway, or (at least) build our thing without this.

We want errors caught by pylint and bandit to break the build... but only if they're important ones.  There currently doesn't seem to be an easy way to separate important issues from trivial style issues.

For now, let builds succeed even if the tools find things.

column1: Use Python SDK on a SOFA Python Product #2
column11: Sensor Open Framework Architecture (SOFA) provides users and application developers with access to data streams and products from the Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS), Defense Support Program (DSP), and select weather (WX) satellite systems.  SOFA is based on legacy Highly Efficient Mission Integrator (HEMI) code.  The SOFA III project on DI2E will provide user community and app developers with greater and more user-friendly access to code and documentation as well as support collaboration.
